title: 112_hr5684
content: The "Password Protection Act of 2012" may be cited as the short title of this Act. Prohibited activity is outlined in Section 2. The "Password Protection Act of 2012" prohibits employers from coercing employees to provide access to protected computers or taking adverse actions against employees who refuse. Section 1030(e) of title 18, United States Code, is amended to define terms like 'employee,' 'employer,' and 'employer's protected computer.' Section 1030(f) of title 18, United States Code is amended to clarify exceptions regarding the authority of a court to grant equitable relief in civil actions related to protecting intellectual property, trade secrets, or confidential business information. The prohibition on employer actions under subsection (a)(8) does not apply if specific facts show the information sought is relevant and material to the employer's interests. The employer can discharge or discipline an individual for good cause without violating the prohibition on employer actions under subsection (a)(8) if the protected activity was not a motivating factor. Additionally, exceptions apply when a State law waives subsection (a)(8) for certain classes of employees or when specific entities within the executive branch waive the prohibition. The National Reconnaissance Office waives subsection (a)(8) for a specific class of employees needing access to classified information under Executive Order 12968 or any successor.
